LeadingFactorBetween1and10.template: When we write a number in scientific notation, remember that we move the decimal point until we get a number between 1 and 10.

GeneralExplanation.description: The leading factor in scientific notation between 1 and 10.
GeneralExplanation.template: {{ student.firstname }}, Nice job moving the decimal point and finding the correct powers of 10 (the $x$ values in your $\cdot 10^{x}$ expressions)! There's one detail that I think you missed about scientific notation: When we write a number in scientific notation, remember that we move the decimal point until that we get a number between 1 and 10. That number between 1 and 10 becomes the factor (or leading factor) that we write in front of the power of ten. Look at your leading factors. Are they between $1$ and $10$? If not, your numbers are not in scientific notation. Can you change them so that they are in scientific notation?

MakingSenseOfPlaceValue.description: Making sense of place value of rational numbers
MakingSenseOfPlaceValue.template: {{ student.firstname }}, look at the notes that I made about the place values of the numbers with decimal points. Look at the largest place value of each one, which I have circled in green, and write the place value as a power of 10 (you can use this table if you need help). Then draw a picture of something that you might see at that scale.
